what makes recovery worth it for you?. i m posting so i can come back and remind myself whenever i want to relapse. here are some things that make recovery worth it to me; healthy hair being able to sit on hard surfaces without pain not being ravenous all the time more stable mood full cheeks soft hydrated skin consistent bathroom habits stronger eyesight enjoying food . . . edit: you guys the response to this post has been wonderfully overwhelming i m so grateful to all of you for further inspiring me to recover i wish each and every one of you the very best wherever you are in your journey

the disordered part of me is fighting back again and is being annoying. i have had a really good large food intake for a few weeks now, but not really enough to have gained more than around gt; 1kg lt;, which all things considered isn't anything. but especially after this weekend, honoring much of my mental hunger, my brain is telling me "the fun is over, you can't continue like this". it's just such a struggle to fight it. no mental approach seems to work; my ed tells me "eating less again will stop weight gain, it will not cause your cholesterol and bloodsugar to be of any concern, you don't restrict enough to actually harm your body in the long run, and if you restrict now you don't have to worry about restricting in the future when you have diabetes society calls you overweight your cholesterol is too high" etc. do i want to recover? do i want to think about food less? i think so? but i am starting to doubt it...i can't seem to convince myself that "taking my life back from the ed" is something i really want, as i barely had a life before it. it seems in my head better to just keep my weight low and eliminate potential health risks such as diabetes stroke for some reason low energy, osteoporosis, lower heart rate etc. don't worry me . to combat this thinking i again free poured my granola; and my ed again said "too much granola, too much milk, too big banana; did you also eat watermelon? don't do that"... and then i ate a measly low cal lunch and my dinner is also going to be too few calories, but i just can't seem to help it today. eds are so annoying when i sometimes want it gone, and other times i don't.

overshoot might never taper down, and y all are gonna have to accept that. i ve been seeing a lot of posts over the past week or so regarding overshoot and worrying that it will never taper down. truth is? it might not. and you have to accept that. the product of overshoot weight is to restore fat to fat free mass; fat is always restored first, so to achieve 1 fat free mass the body has to gain more than 1 fat mass, which is what we call overshoot . my issue with this term is that you don t know if it s overshoot weight. bodies change as we age, and you are not going to have the same body you had as a teenager as you do when you are a fully grown, fully mature adult. hell, do you expect your 2 year old body to look the same at 3 ? at 4 ? after having kids? after health conditions you may develop? after various life experiences? eating disorders are a major fucking strain on the body. there are damages to your organs, brain, bones, digestive system, immune system; you have undergone hormone disruption, catabolism, constant cortisol pumping through your body for months or years. because of this, it is very likely you won t end up with the body you had preed because, well, your preed body hadn t yet undergone the damages of starvation. your preed body didn t require this weight the way it does now. it s unrealistic to expect our bodies to stay the same indefinitely; they are meant to change. we see it from birth into old age. recovery can, and often does, take years . your body isn t stupid it knows how much weight it needs to gain, and it will fight you tooth and nail to get there. it doesn t care about some arbitrary bmi scale rooted in psudoscience, all it knows is that it needs more weight than it did before it was starved to function at its best and heal the various damages you ve caused it. you will very likely feel out of breath often, feel fatigued more quickly, feel less flexible; it might be harder to do the things you did before at a lower weight, even a year into weight restoration but again, you have to remember that your body is still doing a fuckton of repairs that you don t outwardly see on the outside. for example: about 24 months into recovery, i was still dealing with all of the above; my legs and feet would swell from walking on them for only a handful of hours, i d be exhausted at the end of the day, my lungs would burn trying to keep up with my partner doing simple things like going for a walk around the city or a basic hiking trail. it didn t matter that i was going these things regularly 28 months in, i no longer experience breathlessness or constant fatigue, my feet no longer swell up, and i can easily keep up with my partner or go for a simple walk. and i haven t lost a single lb of the overshoot weight i gained at least 3 lbs above my preed set point . on top of that you have all new muscle mass that has not been used trained yet you can t expect to feel strong at least as much as you d like without actually training the muscles first. you build it up like you would if you never had an ed, just like anyone else. is fearing it won t taper down understandable? absolutely i am guilty of hoping my overshoot has tapered down as well but it is rooted in disordered thinking. is it really any different than when you were actively engaging in behaviors and hoping your weight would be lower? obviously if you re recovering you aren t actively engaging in behaviors, but the thought process is the same. it doesn t mean there is absolutely, positively zero chance that it won t taper down, but hyperfixating on it is only going to lead to disappointment if it doesn t, or if it doesn t within a specific timeframe. body image is a state of mind, not a state of being. its not dependent on a set number, it s something you actively work on improving. that is to say, you aren t obligated to like your body post recovery it s entirely okay not to like your recovered body. but you do have to learn to accept it which, yes, can be very difficult if you end up at a much higher weight in a fatphobic society that glorifies thinness, weight loss, and dieting at every turn. and i truly empathize with that. it s not easy. here is a series of important questions to ask ourselves: why am i so hyper focused on this weight? how does this weight make me feel? are these emotions and thoughts patterns productive? what are these emotions and thoughts patterns reinforcing about my body and my self worth; are they rooted in fact, or fear? is this possibly a desire to conform to societal beauty standards that are often unrealistic ? if the weight never tapers down, does that affect my commitment to recovery? if yes, then how can i work on that? if not, then is it truly worth hyperfixating over? what can i do to feel good in my recovered body now that is unrelated to my current weight? what has recovery given me that is not tied to to my weight and the physical appearance of my body?

managing working and eating enough. so basically i d say that on average everyday i m like 1 recovered. only sometimes do i have any kind of disordered thoughts patterns. so just over a month ago i started working full time. now with the work i do the only time i can eat is at lunch. and because i m so busy i don t really feel much hunger due to all the distractions. so on work days i m eating 3 meals with 1 2 serves of fruit and sometimes a random snack when i get home. now on the weekends or on days off i find it hungry wanting a fair bit more food than when i work. my understanding is that on my days off the food intake i have then is what my body wants everyday but i just don t get the chance to do the same everyday. now if this is the case i want to try and incorporate more food into my days when i m at work so my body doesn t feel like i m restricting and go backwards in it s recovery. any ideas for how i can do this? also do you guys think i m on the right track with what it means for this eating pattern? also p.s i m definitely not restricting at all this is just me being aware of how our bodies work and what they need now that i m so far into my recovery.

anyone experience with skinny to strong?. anorexia bulimia smoker here, f35. i used to be obsessed with sports as part of bulimia, but i also felt strong. last 3 years i've quit sports as part of my recovery from gym obsession , and been working from home 2.5 years, smoking at least a pack a day. i'm skinny, so my sick brain wants to keep things the way they are. my diet is poor, as i still want to control it. but i can no longer do any physical activity without being exhausted, and i feel exhausted most of the time. sleeping in weekends for 12 18 hours. it's summer, and i want to do fun stuff, but can't because i have no energy. i've randomly seen inspiring stories of people who recovered, quit smoking and started working out instead. is anyone here who has experienced this miracle and could share? i feel like quitting smoking would be first step, but i'm so exhausted that there is no will power in me. thank you all in advance

coping with rapid weight gain and the question of clothing. okay so due to this community i have come to realize that i actually was not in recovery after my relapse 2 years ago, but rather quasi recovery. i have been giving into my mental hunger the last 5 weeks and, as you can imagine, have been eating a lot. naturally, i am gaining weight rather rapidly, which technically i know is a good thing, a necessity. surprisingly, my issue doesn t lie in the fact that i am gaining weight, but rather with my body changing so, so quickly. i can t keep up. i look in the mirror and just don t recognize the person i see anymore, which is upsetting and confusing my brain a lot, especially since i also don t feel like the person i was anymore, with the active neural rewiring and letting go of my disordered habits. how do you deal with this? when i first was in recovery when i was a teenager i just covered all of my mirrors, but i can say that that was not a good or healthy approach for me. any tips would be welcome. additionally, i m starting to struggle with clothing. i m starting to outgrow all my clothes, however, i don t know how i should proceed from here. i m a student and don t really have a lot of money to spend on clothes even though i already tend to but second hand and since i don t know where this journey is gonna take me and my body, i m worried to buy new clothes only to outgrow them shortly afterwards due to weight gain. do you just buy really stretchy clothes? i also don t want to buy clothes that are way too big because what if i will never fit into them and just bought them for nothing in the end? this is really distressing to be honest. how did do you approach this topic? thank you for reading, any and all comments are greatly appreciated, wishing you the best on your further journey lt;3

through recovery, i've come to realise that my mother triggers my ed behaviours.. tw: self harm, eating disorders. for some background, my mental health problems began at age 1 when my dad went to prison for fraud. my family dynamic immediately shifted into survival mode; my 2 year old brother became the breadwinner and my father figure and my mum began working three jobs to keep the mortgage paid off, my dad also very kindly left many maxxed out credit cards, because he was in jail, they all came after my mum for payment which was hell, all these banks calling the housephone multiple times a day, every day. i became introverted when my dad went to jail, and my nervous anxious picking and scratching at my arms turned into gt; cutting lt; , i managed to hide it until when i was 11, when i reached for something in the supermarket and my mum clocked on when my sleeve slipped. understandably, she was angry, upset and distraught that she hadn't noticed my sh until that point. i got put in therapy and my mum was mega supportive in that she wanted to find a way to help me stop self harming and be around at home more when possible. a concoction of going into an all girls convent school, my dad getting out of prison and hitting puberty lead me to be feel uncomfortable in my body. my self harm became less at points, but i began restricting and purging when i was 13. i went through cycles of this throughout my teens, until i turned strict vegan at 18 and found that it was 1 a huge part of my identity. 2 a way of restricting food groups which people were unable to really challenge or take away from me. my mum has historically been a fad diet lover and complete gym bunny. many of my childhood memories are being taken to the gym playing around whilst my mum worked out 5 days a week. she never directly spoke ill of my appearance, but i was always more of a tomboy that the typical pristine made up essex girl that i think she would of liked me to have been. i met an older guy at 2 , and jetted off travelling for a year and a half. unfortunately, this wasn't great for my mental health, and in order to grasp any type of control over my life, my ed came out full swing. my ed lead to the eventual breakdown of my relationship and me moving back to the uk where i was to recover at my parents home which had it's pros and it's cons . i was diagnosed with atypical anorexia osfed and put into an op treatment programme. i remember having my first "monitor meeting" and being given my food schedule to follow at home and was dreading following it at home due to, what i now realise, my mother's disordered views on food eating. for example: eating once a day: my mum will only eat dinner, and drink coffee instead of eating food. labels foods as: good, bad, treats. if a meal is of a substantial size, it's a "feast" she would call my meals this when i was actively trying to recover, which would set me back. she's fatphobic actively comments on peoples weight or eating habits, which often made me feel scared to recover as someone with body dysmorphia, i believe i was of a much larger body size than i was at this point . if she eats a takeout or what she feels is "too much" will reguarly joke or say that it was enough for a week, "i've eaten this so i can't eat dinner" "it's only light so i can eat ". by some miracle of god, i recovered well whilst in op and entering the pandemic. even to a point where i was able to move out and maintain recovery which felt amazing, even though i struggled with my body image at times. however, moving out, i was able to see so clearly the comments that my mum would make as i was seeing her less. i realised that i would be doing well, on the straight and narrow, and see my parents in which comments would trigger me and make me question my recovery, my body image, everything: at times coming close to relapse because of it. last october, my mh took a dip so i began taking antidepressants. i also chose to start the pill because i was starting training as a nurse i didn't want to fall pregnant before i graduate. although i was nervous about potential weight gain, my studies and very supportive relationship kept me grounded in my recovery. my mum was proud of me for studying, and i really want to achieve well for myself to show myself i can do it. however, i am aware that i feel like i want to reach my mum's expectations, or to feel commended by her. recently, i have felt selfconscious and unformatable around my mum. she has, for some reason, pass comments on my past body; particularly items of clothing she loves me in, clothing from my active disorder. she'll tell me she worries, because she can tell im selfconscious, that i'm not happy in my body, but the thing is, i will feel fine, until i am around her again. i feel like it's a mindgame, a totaly headf ck. because in a time of seeing her, she'll tell me she's proud of the progress i've made, talk sadly of how poorly i was, but then in another conversation compare my "build, limbs, genetics" to that of my dad's side who are overweight, obese . it floors me. my mother has low self esteem, she barely eats herself; my mum, has an eating disorder? i think back to how challenging i could be when i was actively in my ed, the way i would talk about myself or even about others at times; it was my ed talking. one thing i know for sure, i need boundaries and to protect myself from relapse. i so wish, my mum could receive help, therapy to find more confidence in herself. if she knew how this has affected me, impacted me, she would be hurt, broken, feel like she's failed as a mother she has mentioned this when talking about how she feels she failed as a mother when i began struggling with my mental health at 1 . it makes me scared to become a mother, this trauma i need to work through. yesterday, my mum made comments again about my weight, my body. i spend the drive home and all of this morning wondering if i was to shrink myself, to go back to my disorder, would she love me? would i be good enough? at present: i am at the best health i have ever been at 26, have a stable relationship, achieving great grades. but because i'm not a size x, i don't feel good enough for my mother, and i wonder if i ever will be. tldr: i am in a constant head f ck with my mother, she says she's proud of me, but clearly misses how my body presented in my active disorder. i think my mum has an eating disorder and i have adopted many of her disordered behaviours in order to feel accepted by her. i am devastated because i feel that i will never meet her expectations unless i shrink my body.

triggering nurse?. okay, so in my stupidity i looked around online for resources surrounding mental hunger. i think about food all the time despite being full, even if i eat meals and snacks every day and have done for years, and lately i've been eating more calories than before, so probably gt; 25 calories lt; each day. i don't know how long much i restricted, but considering my weight and height gt; 17 cm and 51kg lt;, it makes sense that i'm thinking about food all the time despite eating properly, at least according to this sub and other people in recovery. cue the trigger warning. some nurse and or nutritionist not sure if clinical or not responded to someone who also had mental hunger despite feeling full from eating all the time. they said something along the lines of "you've taught your brain to think about food all the time, and should do some sort of activity to get you mind over on to something else. it can be taking a walk, a bike ride, maybe organized sports or other hobbies. no wonder you're hungry all the time, thinking about food would make you hungry " so this really rubs me the wrong way, and completely invalidates mental hunger, stating it to just be "habitual" and "something you've taught your brain to do". so... am i just mentally weak? did i just, teach my brain to look up pictures of food after eating a huge dinner? should i go for a f cking walk every time i think about food which would in my case just be an excuse and justification to eat even more ? i want to hear your thoughts on this, because now i'm convinced that i'm not actually mentally hungry, i just happen to have taught my brain to obsess over food. oh, and when i play video games, talk to people, take walks, sit in a lecture taking notes i still think about f cking food and i also have a better memory of what my fellow students brought for lunch than what i actually did during the lecture, but i guess that is just because i taught my brain to think about food all the time, correct?

nickelodeon tw: calorie counting . since netflix recently added zoey 1 1, a nickelodeon show, to their roster, i revisited it for my childhood nostalgia. like other kids shows, although the humor was cheesy, there was a charm to it. but omg. it s like the writers on this show were trying to instill a fear of food and weight gain into young girls and boys at such an early age. for example, the main character and her friends all thin young teenagers are all staring at one slice of chocolate cake. one of the friends says she feels weak because she got the chocolate cake and tries to pass it off to her friend, who then refuses it because she s trying to be good , and then passes it to the other friend, who also refuses because that slice of chocolate cake has like a billion calories in it . the friends then decide to only take one bite of the cake slice and that s it. they savor it, and then take one more bite. the friends all exchange satisfied, but guilty looks and the scene ends . in another episode, the opening scene starts with the main character saying ugh, bagels have 3 calories in them . along with instances of characters both girls and guys saying that macaroni and cheese is too carb y , calling thousand island salad dressing fattening, slapping candy out of each other s hands, and feeling guilty for eating salad with a bag of chips, it s no wonder i felt influenced to restrict certain foods even at a young age. another nickelodeon show, icarly, shows a teen girl and her guy friend being angry at another girl for drizzling butter on their popcorn, because now it has tons of calories and is super unhealthy. yet another show, victorious, shows guys complimenting a petite character for weighing 9 pounds this was ariana grande s character . the common theme? they all demonized food and showed unhealthy food relationships to generations of impressionable kids. they were all directed by dan schneider too, a recently revealed pedophilic show director . i just feel so creeped out and upset by all the diet culture in media that was aimed for children

not stable enough for surgery. tw: weight, numbers mention i ve been trying to get into inpatient for so long all that s available for people like me is outpatient or private and i m poor canada . i applied for public inpatient and was rejected bc of my weight. despite them not saying this it s obvious i m 186 lbs, but have been really unstable. i ve never lost weight with ed because of hormone problems yet i have a very restrictive ed that s caused kidney infections, electrolyte issues, and heart problems. lately my heart has been up to 18 bpm standing, and my blood pressure low. my potassium, phosphate, calcium, and sodium are low. in february i had hypokalemia. they said it was critically low potassium. since then i ve been rejected from toronto generals inpatient because my potassium leveled out. note: it leveled out due to to the potassium treatment they gave me during a tachy cardiac episode my levels are still low. i can barely stand. my surgery for endo was cancelled bc i m too unstable and yet by ed standards i m too stable for treatment. i m trying to eat and drink a lot more but it s not getting better. i m scared, and all i can do is wait on a two year wait list for intensive outpatient bc i m not emaciated enough, despite my heart and electrolytes. i m enraged.

does anyone on social media eat normally?. like what s with this guar gum, tapioca flour, almond flour, protein powder, fake sugar bullshit recipes?? what about using oil instead of the stick on stuff?? or whole eggs for once instead of egg whites?? maybe add a fruit every once in a while. how about rice or bread or potatoes instead of some grain yall were probably making fun of people from other cultures in school for eating but is now popular like buckwheat and quinoa . any type of protein other than protein powder and chicken breast? beans and other types of meats and proteins exist too shits expensive guys. i know it s not everyone but seriously why is everyone eating these concoctions of like idk if i would call it fake food but it certainly doesn t seem too normal to me i worked in a grocery store for a long ass time and let me tell you what most ppl get: frozen food, convenience foods, ice cream, dairy milk, eggs, all kinds of meat, cereal, hot dogs, deli meat, bread, chips, cookies, pasta, sauces. i know the standard american diet isn t the healthiest, but i saw people of all shapes and sizes buy these. some bought more unhealthy food while others bought more healthy food and more produce. i grew up in a household of just ingredients, so we rarely had snacks like chips and sugary foods like cereal, but we still had it occasionally. my mom cooked meals from scratch because as an immigrant she missed home, but i know not all people have the time to cook or even like cooking. but never did we have this oat fiber guar gum coconut flour protein powder anabolic shit which is just a junk food diet disguised as healthy. that shit gives people stomach issues. what the fuck is this?? go travel and see if you can maintain that diet without having to bring your stupid powders everywhere. they always made a mess for me.

will the overshoot weight ever go down? losing hope.. i'm having a very hard time lately. i've always been naturally slim, but after the initial weight gain, i gained the same amount on top of that. i've weight restored a little over a year ago, i'd say april may 2 21, also got my period back around that time. it's not even just about the weight, but i just can't get used to having such a completely different body type. i've had to buy an entire new wardrobe, even tshirts didn't fit me anymore. literally had to give everything away that i wore before, even lose, oversize cut dresses are so tight i can't wear them anymore. it's also difficult because i feel like i'm just too heavy for my body, if that makes sense. i'm getting sweaty and hot extremely fast now, i've actually started sweating a lot, having sweat run down my face even when i'm not being active which never happened before. i'm having a hard time doing yoga because, no matter how hard i try, my arms can't seem to hold up my weight, even in relatively easy asanas. i get out of breath when taking the stairs, and i don't have a lot of energy bloodwork's fine, everything's fine according to my doctor . my anorexia started when i was 2 i'm 25 now , so it's not like i was a teenager. i'd been at the same weight and size for years pre ed. i miss the body i had before my ed, i'm scared that i've ruined my metabolism and the overshoot weight will never go down. how long did it take you to lose the overshoot weight? did you notice anything different about your appetite, your energy levels, anything? did you do anything differently around that time? please give me some reassurance that it actually is possible to lose the overshoot weight. i'm losing hope and i miss the way i used to look pre ed. and on a final note: i'm actually begging you not to tell me that worrying about my weight is disordered. i haven't weighed myself in a year. i've been in therapy for 3 years. i eat enough. i have a balanced diet. i stopped working out excessively, mainly doing yoga these days. i think it's normal that i want my old body shape back, that i want to feel like me again in my body. and i just want to wear my vintage levi's and my old summer dresses again, buying new clothes all the time is getting so expensive and thrifting is not an option where i live.
has anyone experienced kl3ptomania during their eating disorder?. it's not something i'm proud of, but one way to gain control, or a "reward" was by stealing stupid diet food from supermarkets lol

feeling full. everytime i eat and feel full i m in shock. like i just had noodles and i m full?? some days i need to eat like a million snacks but i got tired of that and just made my meals slightly larger portions and it s so much better. i ll still eat a snacky snack but wow it s been like 2 months since i started feeling full and i m still not used to it.

allowed myself to eat the whole serving . today, my family wanted to order chinese food. back then, i would have completely freaked out internally, or locked myself in my room just to not be "tempted", or order something small which i didn't really want to begin with. but today, since i've been trying to recover for about a month now, i allowed myself to order chow mein carbs were one of my very intense fear foods and some orange chicken, which is something i actually wanted. i ate my meal and i enjoyed it so much and the cherry on top i guess, is that i finished the entire serving without feeling ultra guilty instead of cutting the portion by half or taking only a few bites. i know this may seem not that impressive or important at all, but i just wished to share because enjoying food is such a great feeling. i hope good days like these keep on coming so, if you're reading this, this is also a sign for you to go ahead and eat what you're craving :

doubts about extreme hunger. after doing a lot of research on my own on extreme hunger, it makes a lot of sense to me to honor it. however, when i brought it up to my dietician and pediatrician, they told me that although it is normal to be ravenously hungry after being malnourished, "honoring" it, and eating large quantities of food is extremely harmful and now she is telling me i may have or be developing binge eating disorder. i'm really scared about this possible diagnosis, however i do stop eating when i'm full, and eat only when i'm hungry. the only thing is when i get ravenously hungry i definitely feel out of control while eating an extremely large quantity of food. i don't really know what to believe now, because although many people recovering from eating disorders themselves say to honor hunger, medical professionals are telling me otherwise. for now i think i'll just stick to my meal plan and not eat more.

recovery question. is it normal to be crazy bloated? i just ate a peach and now i look like i m pregnant. but my bloating isn t uncomfortable. here s some background: i struggled with anorexia and restricting for abt 3 years and then binging for 1 year. i m trying to recover but every time i eat something i have to sit down for like 3 minutes after for it to even be comfortable to walk. even something as small as a peach. it s honestly ridiculous.
playing volleyball in recovery. so i will be playing volleyball in recovery i m like 75 sure. thoughts?

maple syrup?. i was feeling in an adventurous mood and wanted to mix up my oatmeal, so i made the usual milk, oats, salt, cinnamon, cardamom, peanut butter and raisins; but i wanted something other than jam so i tried maple syrup, which i haven't really eaten before. now why did nobody tell me how bloody delicious maple syrup is? why do i not have it on absolutely everything? if you haven't tried genuine maple syrup, i highly suggest you do

recovery made easy. i honestly wish i had a personal chef that would cook me three delicious meals a day or that i had money to order food three times a day. cooking is so stressful and i can t stop looking at calories in food packages or stop weighing everything i eat. why am i like this.

my partner makes my recovery a overwhelming experience. tw numbers recovery by itself is already a tough thing but my partner is the one who keeps eyes on me and o make sure i'm trying to follow my meal plan which i keep failing . but i hate thst he needs to sit with me to make sure i'm having at least 3 big meals a day. i hate when i say i'm not hungry or my stomach is aching, he doesn't believe in me. he is always saying that i'm sick even though i don't recognize it or that i have to eat my meals not matter what. it's hurting me a lot. i can't go all in like he wants me to do. but he keeps pressuring me to eat. he recently learned about the 3 cal minimum for recovery and he's bothering me to have it when i barely can have 15 . it's like for him all my problems will be resolved by eating my meals. i'm so tired of it.

shame and guilt. i'm trying to honour my extreme hunger, but the only way i can even contemplate it is to eat in bed where no one can see me, and generally try to pretend it's not happening. and my body is changing so rapidly i literally would rather die than let anyone see me right now, which means i'm spending all non eating time in bed too. the only time i can consider letting anyone see me eat is if i'm having perfectly portioned "healthy" food. the whole thing is so embarrassing i hate this process and i hate feeling like this but i don't know what else to do other than to stop eating again

any advice for not relapsing after 5 months of recovery?. so i m in my second round of recovery last was 5 years ago, relapsed 2 years ago and i took this recovery by slowly eating more, cut down on my exercise etc. now everyday i pretty much eat to my hunger cues, no longer restrict carbs fats and exercise on par w probably an average pretty active person vs hours and hours per day the problem is that as an obvious result my body has filled back out now that i m not restricting heavily or exercising for hours a day. the result of that is that i m now near the point and far enough from restriction that i feel like i m having more and more thoughts that since i m a healthy weight again it s time to relapse and lose these extra lbs to get closer to me beloved low weight. anyone have tips? logically i honestly will probably lose the relationship with the love of my life if i get to my low again, he is so supportive and loving but getting me through last winter when i was at a low physically and mentally, he has told me he loves me but cannot, for his own health, mentally go through it again. i also feel like i ve already forgotten the lows that come with that body, the only body i actually like . lows like literally barely being able to function at my high level data analyst career because all i could think about, at all, was the next time i could eat. the lows like forcing myself in rain and even snow storms in negative temperatures to go for runs. i feel like somehow i ve forgotten all that pain already now that i haven t been working out to that extreme or restricting to those levels. this has kind of turned into a rant and maybe that s what i needed but any advice on how to get over the hump are super welcome.

question about bed. i have a genuine question, because i can't seem to really understand bed. i know it's a way of numbing feelings by purposefully "hiding" in food; but how do you know you actually have bed? i personally have a restrictive ed, and i think about food all the time. i "plan" and want to eat things like a large pizza, 15 2 grams of chocolate, a cup of hot cocoa, and a big bag of assorted candy today. if i don't eat the things i "plan", i kind of feel a bit dissapointed, like i restricted all the things i wanted, despite being full to the brim. if i were to eat all of the things i mentioned, would that be a moment of planned binging? i don't think i'm using it to numb any feelings or anything, and it isn't like i lose control, since i choose how much i want beforehand... i also don't instantly consume it, but kind of savor it and really enjoy it with a good movie. the reason i doubt myself is because i feel like it can't be "extreme hunger"; i justify that by saying things like "i've eaten 4 proper meals with occasional snacks every day for a couple of years", and i think i average around gt; 27 calories lt; each day, or have done so for many weeks months now. i'm just confused and scared i might have another ed than i believe i have, if that makes sense?

is it normal to miss your residential treatment once you leave?. i just got back from res a few days ago, and i miss it so much. my php seems horrible compared to my residential, and i miss everyone there so much. has anyone else been through this?

wtf is going on lol. i think my body has been like holy shit, we are actually consistently getting fed now because my hormones are going bezerk. my sex drive has been going through the roof and i m not feeling as tired anymore. listening to my body is finally paying off i m sorry i ever restricted you body

my order at starbucks 5 years ago vs today. 5 years ago my best friend and i went to starbucks. even though i hate plain black coffee, i ordered it because i was so afraid of liquid calories . today, i went again with her and i proudly ordered a mocha frappuccino because that was what i was craving. sorry ana, you no longer control what i order when i'm out with my friend.
